3 BD mgmt and monitoring tools adapted and in application

An element that has contributed to the functioning of the project and achievement of its goals is the generation of knowledge products These tools serve to support producers and technical service providers in implementing practices that contribute to biodiversity conservation Additionally they are useful to public servants mainly of the CONAFOR and the SEMARNAT for giving opinions on forest management projects and support resources
In this regard the following four new knowledge products have also been developed during this period
1 Road Manual Techniques to Control el Sediment on Secondary Forest Roads
2 Forest Management Reserva Forestal Multifuncional El Manantial SC Concepts Conduct and Actions
3 Forest Habitat Characterization and Classification Guide
4 General guidelines to incorporate biodiversity conservation into FMPs for utilization of timber forest resources
The documents along with the Manual produced in 2013 have been published for consultation on the CONAFOR page httpwwwconaforgobmxwebtemasforestalesbiodiversidad Five new knowledge products have been created representing 166 of the planned goal
The HCV Identification Guide reported in the previous period is a document that considers a broad conceptual framework to identify High Conservation Values a process which needs to be more operational
Additionally other knowledge products are being developed which are expected to be completed no later than June 2016
b A crucial element in implementing actions promoted by the project has been capacity building among different forestry sector stakeholders In this regard the reporting period has been the one with the greatest number of training events and persons trained From June 2014 to July 2015 104 training events took place which 1782 people attended Of these people 16 are technical personnel from the CONAFOR 5 from the SEMARNAT 1 from the PROFEPA 15 from the CONABIO 05 from the CONANP 46 are Technical Service Providers 6 are from State Governments 14 are academics and 9 are from NGOs To date 1289 forest producers or CFE members have been trained
Of the people trained 24 now have knowledge of technical aspects and practices related to biodiversity conservation 26 have strengthened their forest management capacities 8 now have the technical capacities and knowledge to develop a biological monitoring system 1 have the technical capacities and knowledge to develop an HCV study 16 have knowledge of the countrys certification tools and 24 have received specialized consulting on the issue of competitiveness and markets
We highlight the 491 women who attended training events during this period and who represent 16 of the total persons who attended
Cumulatively 194 training events on the different mentioned topics have been recorded In these 3620 people from institutions NGOs TFSPs and academics have participated representing progress of 1206 with respect to the planned goal Additionally 1739 CFE members have participated
In the Perception Study and Capacity Assessment commissioned by the project a section was dedicated precisely to assessing to what extent training actions have helped to strengthen the capacities of the main stakeholders on issues promoted by the projectFor purposes of comparison groups of people under project intervention and not under project intervention were defined Specifically for TFSPs a set of questions of high technical difficulty was designed the questions were validated with experts
In this regard the average score or percentage of correct answers given by the TFSPs under project intervention was 82 meanwhile the TFSPs not under project intervention obtained a score of 65 which shows a notable difference of 17 between both groups

One of the projects main areas of opportunity is the development of national government demand for certified timber It is a complex issue that requires the involvement of several federal agencies SHCP SEMARNAT SEP etc However the project has made progress in generating information and projects that can have an impact on consolidating the demand for certified forest products by public institutions
Study of the sawn timber market
In December 2014 the Study of the Sawn Timber Market in Mexico was finalized It includes an analysis of market conditions and sawn timber from tropical species in Mexico and the demand for certified timber products by the federal government state governments and the private sector
National Wood Energy Program
As part of the projects strategies to develop and diversify the demand for products derived from sustainable forest management the implementation of projects to generate electricity from forest biomass has been identified as a viable option In this regard the project financed the implementation of the National Wood Energy Program PRONADEN from which a first draft was already generated which underwent validation before a group of experts and the comments received are in process of being addressedApart from containing the strategies to be followed by the project and the CONAFOR on power generation through forest biomass
Green Procurement Decree
Through the Forest Development Office and in collaboration with the project the CONAFOR is reviewing the Decree whereby Various Measures for Procurement Paper Usage and Certification of Sustainable Forest Management by the Federal Government better known as the Green Procurement Decree and the Law on Procurement Leasing and Services for the Public Sector
Based on an analysis of these regulations it is necessary to adjust them therefore a proposal for additions and reforms must be presented that will define what the mechanism will be to ensure traceability of national certified products from harvesting areas to consumers
This is intended to encourage and promote purchases of certified products that are required by public entities and includes the responsibilities and obligations of those who are hired for construction services within the Public Administration in order to ensure that the wood used also comes from certified sourcesThe proposal will be presented to SEMARNAT to form a working group to examine what adjustments are requiredThe preliminary proposal is set to be ready by the end of 2015
Likewise the project will make any necessary adjustments to its planning by seeking to free up resources to hire a specialized consultant who may follow up on this issue from the review of the Decree and Law on Procurement to the drafting of a specific proposal to amend the mentioned legislation and make proposals for procurement protocols at the state level
Michoacán Procurement Agreement
The Michoacán Government Procurement Agreement has failed to materialize because the state has had three different governors who all have installed their own working teams upon taking power which has led to constant changes in the key positions involved in the signing of the Agreement
Regarding the goal of procurement contractsagreements entered into with public institutions the former partner of the Project the Rainforest Alliance RA was working with the CFE el Balcón Guerrero to make sales of certified products However these developments were not reported because the evidence of such purchases and sales was not availableIn November 2014 as part of the proof of the resources entrusted to them the RA presented 16 invoices for 12 procurement contracts that were signed by agencies of the State Government of Guerrero and by a municipal governmentIn the 2013 PIR three more formalized agreements had been reported which reaches the goal of 15 certified timber procurement agreementscontracts with public institutions

a As reported in the previous period forest certification and biodiversity conservation are priorities established in the National Forestry Program One indicator of the importance of forest certification to the Mexican government is the national goal set in the PRONAFOR to triple certified area by 2018 which is leading to a substantial increase in institutional investment intended to support forest certification
The Mexican Standard NMXAA143SCFI2008 for certification of sustainable forest management has been strengthened with project inputs by making the criteria related to biodiversity conservation mandatory as well as identifying high conservation value attributes connectivity of habitats and conservation of vertical and horizontal structures essential for biodiversity conservation
The project also has participated in incorporating and strengthening the Mexican Forest Certification Council A consultancy was hired to develop the Internal Rules of Operation and support said Councils formalization process before a notary public
Through a consultant hired by the project the Manual establishing the guidelines for Preventive Technical Audits was amended strategic changes were made for its concurrence with the Mexican Standard on certification of sustainable forest management along with changes to the National Forestry Certification SystemRecently the process to update the FSC International Certification Standard began The project is participating in the review of 3 of its criteria which will promote the incorporation of biodiversity conservation and a gender approach
Also in response to one of the main recommendations of the MidTerm Review on promoting the drafting of a chain of custody standard the project has participated in drafting and reviewing the assessment procedure for chain of custody forestry processes developed by the Asociación de Normalización y certificación AC ANCE
bThe project contributed to amendments to the PRONAFOR Rules of Operation for 2013 2014 and 2015 in collaboration with the Offices of Forest Development Community Forest Development and Supply Chain Integration thereby providing technical inputs to the National Sustainable Forest Management Strategy for Increasing Production and Productivity
Moreover the Project financed the implementation of eight regional courses on regulation management and forest health coordinated by the Secretariat of Environment and Natural Resources which were attended by 1700 people from the SEMARNAT PROFEPA CONAFOR CONANP TFSPs academics forest producers and othersIt is worth mentioning that through these courses it was possible to hasten acceptance of biodiversity conservation among public servants and other stakeholders mentioned above
